Course Section: AMNE_V 101-001 - Greek and Latin Roots of English
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Greek and Latin Roots of English. Old course code: CLST 101. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.
This is an asynchronous web-based course. You may register in this course even if the time conflicts with another course.

Greek and Roman Mythology. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

**This lecture section only meets MW. Please register separately for Friday's class in an associated discussion section**

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Course Section: AMNE_V 160-001 - Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Jewish, Christian, and Muslim Religious Traditions. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions. Cross-listed with RGST 160 001.

** This course has TWO required sections: a lecture and a discussion. This lecture section only meets MW. Please email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with your ranked preference for Friday’s discussion section. You will be assigned to a discussion section depending on your enrolment time and seat availability.**
The discussion sections are: 
AMNE 160 L1A:  F 9-10 am
AMNE 160 L1B:   F 10-11 am
AMNE 160 L1C:  F 11-12 pm
 
If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

Course Section: AMNE_V 160-L1D - Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Steps for registration:

** This course has TWO required sections: a lecture and a discussion. **

Please register for AMNE 160 L1D in order to complete your registration for AMNE 160 001 (lecture). WD will not allow you to register for the lecture section unless you also register for this DISC section (AMNE 160 L1D).
This lecture section only meets MW. Please email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with your ranked preference for Friday’s discussion sections. You will then be moved from L1D into your assigned discussion section (L1A, L1B, or L1C) depending on your enrolment time and seat availability.

The discussion sections options are: 
AMNE 160 L1A:  F 9-10 am
AMNE 160 L1B:   F 10-11 am
AMNE 160 L1C:  F 11-12 pm

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section. If the course is blocked by showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

This course is part of the Coordinated Arts Program, Law & Society stream,   
https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/streams/law-society/. Students must register in both Term  
1 and Term 2 courses in CAP. 
 
Please register in both the lecture, and one of the following discussion sections: ANTH_V 100-A_D2A, ANTH_V 100-A_D2B, ANTH_V 100-A_D2C, or ANTH_V 100-A_D2D. This course is also clustered with HIST_V 104-A_227, and the Law & Society sections of the CAP stream seminar CAP_V 100. For HIST_V 104-A_227, please register in the lecture, and one of the following discussion sections: HIST_V 104-A_L1A, HIST_V 104-A_L1B, HIST_V 104-A_L1C, or HIST_V 104-A_L1D. For CAP_V 100, please register in one of the following: CAP_V 100-L01, CAP_V 100-L02, CAP_V 100-L03, or CAP_V 100-L04. CAP_V 100 does not have any additional discussion sections. Follow the prompts to register in all stream seminars (1), lectures (2), and tutorials (1-2) each term. 
 
For step-by-step instructions, please visit: https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/program/registration/ 
 
If you encounter any issues with registration into CAP, please contact us at support.fyip@ubc.ca

This course explores the diverse tapestry of human cultures through the lens of cultural anthropology. It examines fundamental concepts, methodologies, and thematic explorations shaping this field of study. From language to politics, from rituals to virtual spaces, cultural anthropologists analyze the intricacies of societies worldwide. Through lectures, discussions, and immersive activities, we will explore the notion of 'culture' and the method of participant-observation. Engaging with ethnographic accounts, we will investigate the familiar and the unfamiliar, learning to challenge perspectives, question norms, and cultivate critical thinking.

Direct registration into this course is blocked. Registration into APSC 100 is via a first year engineering timetable. If you require APSC 100, but aren't registered in a first year timetable, please register via the waitlist.  

Please use the UBC Directory to find your instructor/TA contact information.
